contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Quillfish | image = Ptilichthys goodei 2.jpg | image_width = 240px | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[Actinopterygii]] | ordo = [[Perciformes]] | familia = '''Ptilichthyidae''' | genus = '''''Ptilichthys''''' | species = '''''P. goodei''''' | binomial = ''Ptilichthys goodei'' | binomial_authority = [[Tarleton Hoffman Bean|Bean]], 1881 }} The '''quillfish''', ''Ptilichthys goodei'', is a species of [[perciform]] fish, the [[monotypic|only species]] in the genus '''''Ptilichthys''''' and family '''Ptilichthyidae'''. It is an elongate [[eel]]-like fish that reaches 34 cm in length. It is native to the north [[Pacific Ocean]], from the [[Bering Sea]] down to [[Oregon]].<ref>{{FishBase family | family = Ptilichthyidae | year = 2006 | month = February}}</ref><ref>{{FishBase species | genus = Ptilichthys | species = goodei | year = 2006 | month = February}}</ref> It has been found on the surface at night, attracted by the lights of fishing boats, but little is known about its daytime habits; it is thought that it may burrow in sandy and muddy bottoms during the day, emerging at dusk to feed. Quillfishes have been found in the stomachs of juvenile [[Coho salmon]], ''Oncorhynchus kisutch'', and [[Chinook salmon]], ''Oncorhynchus tshawytscha''. The longest quillfish was nearly as long (82%) as its [[predator]].<ref>{{cite journal | title = Quillfish, ''Ptilichthys goodei'', Filiform Prey for Small Coho and Chinook Salmon | author = Laurie A. Weitkamp | journal = Alaska Fishery Research Bulletin | volume = 11 | issue = 1 | year = 2005}}</ref> ==References== * {{ITIS |id=171553 |taxon=Ptilichthys goodei |accessdate=18 April 2006}} <references/> [[Category:Ptilichthyidae]] [[Category:Monotypic fish genera]] [[Category:Animals described in 1881]]
